hi.hi: Feargus O’Connor in Parliament. Views of the Continental Press.

div.p: The Reforme, Paris paper, says, in speaking of the Irish Coercion Bill, Mr John O’Connell has found a formidable rival in Mr O’Connor. This great democratic leader has placed himself at one bound at the head of the Irish party. It was he alone who fully opposed the Coercion Bill. It was he who lead the opposition. It was he who opposed every clause, and retarded to the utmost the passing of the bill. It was he who concentrated in his speeches the whole spirit of the opposition. It was he, in fine, who, for the first time since 1835, brought forward a motion for Repeal, which no other Irish member would have done.

The Irish members have bowed to his leadership with but a bad grace. Whigs in their hearts, they hate the democratic energy of Mr. O’Connor. He will no longer allow them to make Repeal a sordid cry of faction. The real Repeal members, however, cannot do without such a leader as O’Connor, and are obliged to submit, athough they try to undermine his growing popularity in Ireland.

After the session, Mr O’Connor will probably make the tour of Ireland, to re-create the agitation, and found a true democracy. No doubt he will succeed, and in less than six months be the recognised leader of the Irish people.
Uniting thus the guidance of the democracy in the three kingdoms, he will be placed in a position stronger than any agitator, including O’Connell, has ever yet occupied.

The Brussels German Gazette of the 9th inst., in an article entitled,
Feargus O’Connor and the Irish People,
dispatiates at great length on Mr O’Connor’s address in the Northern Star of the 1st inst., and observes: “This address ought to be read and treasured by every democrat. The results of this magnificent address will soon show themselves with a powerful influence. ... Feargus O’Connor is the man that Ireland wants. He has the wealth of millions truly at heart — their welfare is, with him, no empty cry, no mask to get government patronage.

In his address he shows the Irish people how, for thirteen years, it has been led by the nose by Daniel O’Connell, the political thimble-rigger, with the cry of ‘Repeal’. He places in its proper light the conduct of John O’Connell, his father’s political heir, and who, like his father, sacrifices millions of credulous Irishmen to his personal plans and interests — but all the fine words and hypocrisy of John O’Connell will be insufficient to wipe away the stain he has contracted in the ‘Coercion Bill’ Debate. This address must open the eyes of the Irish people, and it will then spurn the knot of sham Repealers who laugh in their sleeves at their credulity.

But the address has greater importance still, as emanating, not only from an Irishman, but also from an English Democrat and Chartist. He shows with a clearness that must carry conviction even to the most obtuse, the necessity for a close union between the Irish and the English working classes; and that Repeal can only be successful for Ireland when joined with the Charter. He further points to the fact that the English Chartists petitioned to the number of three and a half millions for Repeal — that they have now again petitioned against the Coercion Bill — and that the oppressed of both countries must stand or fall together.”
The Cologne Gazette observes, in allusion to Mr O’Connor, his motion for Repeal, and his address in the Star: —

“Descended from the oldest aristocracy of Ireland, nay! tracing his pedigree to the remote and chivalrous kings of Green Erin; intimately connected with the misfortunes of his country, through the sufferings of his more immediate ancestors; constantly busied with her present fortunes and her future prospects, O’Connor stands before us, a specimen of those men who remind us at once of past glories and of future hopes; and from whose lips we receive with equal pleasure the traditions of the former, and the prophecies of the coming times.

Parliament sees with terror that Daniel O’Connell has found a successor in his countryman, Feargus O’Connor, who once more brings forward the question of Repeal, and whose indomitable perseverance bodes a more formidable struggle than that waged by the deceased O’Connell.

In his speech on Repeal, O’Connor described the history of this country with appalling accuracy. He described the fall of his royal ancestry. He narrated the sufferings of his noble hearted and betrayed countrymen. As you hear him, the crushed Catholic writhing in his blood, the war-cry of a hundred revolts is recalled to your memory — the whole history of unhappy Erin, all the woes of the ‘Niobe of nations’ are spread before you.

The first number of the Northern Star for this year contains an admirable address from Mr O’Connor to the Irish people, recommending the Charter as a necessary concomitant with Repeal, since the one without the other, would be incomplete.”

We have received copies of the following Dutch papers: — De Burger (the Citizen) and the Batavian Courier, both published at the Hague, containing columns of the proceedings of the English Chartists and the Fraternal Democrats. The editor, M. Adrien van Bevarvoorde, appears to be a talented, eloquent and energetic defender of the principles of Democracy.
The Reforme of Monday last contains a translation of the address of the Fraternal Democrats to the working men of Great Britain and Ireland, published in our last number.
